title: We Sail Tonight For Singapore
summary:
Key ideas
- Singapore is widely regarded as a model government for Reactionaries.
- It follows Reactionary-ish policies and is a nice place to live.
- The post aims to examine whether its Reactionary policies cause its good government.
- Another city-state with high levels of self-government, Hong Kong, will also be analysed.

Key learnings
- Singapore is an exceptionally well-run country with no natural resources and a small land area.
- Hong Kong shares most of Singapore's advantages, and therefore Singapore did well because of other factors.
- Supercapitalist Chinese-British city-states tend to do really well regardless of whether they are notably Reactionary or not.

Key questions
- Can we conclude that Singapore's Reactionary policies cause its good government?
- Might Singapore have just been an exceptionally well-run country that by coincidence chose to follow Reactionary policies?
- Do supercapitalist Chinese-British city-states do really well regardless of their political ideology?
